> > Do I really have to repeat myself over and over again?
> No, because the question was about XML and your solution won't work for
> several reasons:
> 1. The indention may be different.
> 2. The sequence of the attributes may be different.
> 3. The result may have attributes that are allowed but not mandatory.
> 4. The encoding might be different.
> 
> A string compare can only be done on exclusively canonized XML.

Did anyone hear my saying "String comparison"?  If this is the case, then I have
to shout out louder.

<ads>
If you need a specialized assert class, first take a look at junit-addons on sf.
 Some additional classes in the main release + additional one in the sandbox cvs
module.  List ListAssert, JndiAssert, DOMAssert (yes DOM, like in XML, like in
the question I answered, qed)
And soon a new runner and some pmd rules.
</ads>

But if you want, you can do a string comparison.

-Vladimir
